channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rishi Sunak Becomes the Front Runner for U.K. Prime Minister
item.description: Mr. Sunak’s warnings about inflation and his fiscal conservatism may have cost him the post in September. But now his accurate assessments are easing his path to Britain’s top job.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Hannah Mckay/Reuters
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak at a Conservative Party event in London in August.

item.title: Math Scores Fell in Nearly Every State, and Reading Dipped on National Exam
item.description: The results, from what is known as the nation’s report card, offer the most definitive picture yet of the pandemic’s devastating impact on students.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh and Ashley Wu
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Not a single state was able to improve test scores for math.

item.title: Bring Back Competitive Admissions? Some NYC Middle Schools May Not.
item.description: After a pandemic moratorium, city leaders are letting school superintendents decide whether to bring back some admissions requirements that critics say feed racial disparities.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York City schools chancellor, David C. Banks, said he would allow middle schools to resume using selective admissions, but many may not.

item.title: Why Detroit Won’t Elect a Black Democrat to Congress
item.description: Shri Thanedar’s primary victory means that for the first time in 70 years, America’s largest majority Black city may not send a Black representative to Washington.
item.dc:creator: Clyde McGrady
item.media:credit: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: State Representative Shri Thanedar, a 67-year old Indian American multimillionaire, beat eight African American candidates in the Democratic primary for Michigan’s 13th Congressional District.

item.title: In Ohio Senate Race, Tim Ryan Often Avoids the Word ‘Democrat’
item.description: Mr. Ryan, the Ohio Democrat who is challenging J.D. Vance, has turned the state into perhaps the country’s unlikeliest Senate battleground.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Gaelen Morse for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Tim Ryan is in contention in a state that Donald Trump twice carried by eight points and Democrats had effectively written off.

item.title: How Abortion Is Shaping the NY Governor’s Race
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul has made abortion access the defining issue of her campaign. Her challenger, Representative Lee Zeldin, opposes the procedure but has promised not to change the state’s rules.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York has long had some of the nation’s strongest abortion protections.

item.title: Their America Is Vanishing. Like Trump, They Insist They Were Cheated.
item.description: The white majority is fading, the economy is changing and there’s a pervasive sense of loss in districts where Republicans fought the outcome of the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Michael H. Keller and David D. Kirkpatrick
item.media:credit: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine War Amputees Find New Limbs, and Hope
item.description: It did not take long for amputees to begin coming off the Ukrainian battlefield. Our photographer captured their fight to lead ordinary lives again.
item.dc:creator: David Guttenfelder and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fellow soldiers, their loved ones, and hospital staff. gather in the hallway with curiosity and to show support for Semyon, 27, as he takes his first steps on his new leg prosthetic leg in the hallway of a hospital in the town of Truscavets on August 26, 2022. By his side is his wife Vika, 24. Semyon, who is a radio operator and signalman for the 11 anti-aircraft misslie battery. lost his leg to a Russian mortar barrage in Ukraine’s Kharkiv region. He says that his unit was shelled 43 times in 20 minutes between 6:20-6:40 am on that day. Was born in Reni, in the Odesa region and has been a professional combatant for the Ukrainian military since 2019.

item.title: Western Allies Reject Russia’s ‘Dirty Bomb’ Claims
item.description: Diplomats from France, Britain and the United States called Russia’s allegation a pretext that Moscow has concocted for escalating the war.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Maxim Shemetov/Reuters
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin and Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu in August. Mr. Shoigu held calls with his counterparts from France, the U.S. and Britain over the weekend.

item.title: Why the Family of an NFL Player Is Suing a Real Housewives Star
item.description: She lost her only son, a former N.F.L. player. A settlement would have provided some solace, but even that was taken away.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas and Morgan Lieberman
item.media:description: Photos of Chuck Osborne, who played football at the University of Arizona and in the N.F.L., are displayed in the home of his mother, Kathleen Bajgrowicz.

item.title: Hasidic School to Pay $8 Million After Admitting to Federal Fraud
item.description: The Central United Talmudical Academy, which operates the largest all-boys yeshiva in New York State, acknowledged illegally diverting money from federal food aid and other programs.
item.dc:creator: Brian M. Rosenthal and Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The operators of the Central United Talmudical Academy in Brooklyn admitted in federal court to diverting government money in a wide-ranging fraud.

item.title: A Lonely Protest in Beijing Inspires Young Chinese to Find Their Voice
item.description: As beginner dissenters, they’re timid and scared. But they are experiencing a quiet political awakening, unhappy about censorship, repression and “zero Covid.”
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

item.title: Madhur Jaffrey’s Undefinable Roles
item.description: The chef, author and actress, whose children’s book, “Seasons of Splendour,” was reissued this month, refuses to be boxed in.
item.dc:creator: Thessaly La Force
item.media:credit: Adrianna Newell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Madhur Jaffrey, shown here at her home in Hillsdale, New York, continues to publish recipes and articles, appear on podcasts, give interviews and speak in documentaries — even rapping in a music video with the artist Mr. Cardamom.

item.title: We May Have Only a Few Months to Prevent the Next Pandemic
item.description: The window to act is closing fast.
item.dc:creator: Craig Spencer

item.title: This Wasn’t the Vibe Shift Democrats Had in Mind
item.description: Republicans are threatening to peak at exactly the wrong moment for Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kari Lake appears to be on a roll in Arizona.

item.title: Why OPEC Is Cutting Oil Production (and Why There’s Not Much the U.S. Can Do About It)
item.description: Washington sees OPEC Plus’s decision to cut oil production as support for Russia, but Saudi Arabia had legitimate economic reasons for pushing it.
item.dc:creator: Ellen R. Wald
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:credit: Ahmed Jadallah/Reuters
item.media:description: On Oct. 5, a group of oil producers led by Saudi Arabia decided to cut oil production quotas by two million barrels per day starting in November.

item.title: Biden and Trump Share One Thing
item.description: They may be the two weakest presidents since before the progressive era.
item.dc:creator: Yuval Levin
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Photographs by Glowimages, maximkabb, and wilatlak villette via Getty

item.title: The Way Los Angeles Is Trying to Solve Homelessness Is ‘Absolutely Insane’
item.description: Developing affordable housing projects shouldn’t make a miserable existence for those who’ve devoted their lives to it.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeremiah Dean, near an encampment in the parking lot where the Venice Dell Community project may be built in Los Angeles. Mr. Dean is homeless and has been living in a tent in the parking lot for more than three months.

item.title: Kari Ann Lake’s Hijacking of Martin Luther King
item.description: Like Donald Trump, she is invoking the civil rights icon in self-serving ways.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

item.title: For New York Governor, The Times Endorses Kathy Hochul
item.description: In-person voting begins on Oct. 29.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Jingyu Lin for The New York Times

item.title: A Republican Advantage
item.description: As headlines shift in the weeks before the midterms, so do voters’ top concerns.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Running an Election in the Heart of Election Denialism
item.description: A conversation with Stephen Richer, the chief election officer in Maricopa County, Ariz.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Eric Krupke, Nina Feldman, Mike Benoist, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Michael Chow/The Arizona Republic, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Stephen Richer is the top election official in Maricopa Country, Ariz. Many of the voters in the state doubt the legitimacy of the electoral process.

item.title: Has Polling Broken Politics?
item.description: As the midterms near, Margie Omero and Nate Silver consider what voter surveys are good for.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Facing Surgery? Here’s How to Prepare.
item.description: The best way to navigate a surgery recommendation is to ask a lot of questions.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Joan Wong; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: At Least 2 Killed in Shooting at St. Louis High School
item.description: At least seven others were injured in the shooting, at Central Visual and Performing Arts High School, the authorities said. The gunman died after exchanging gunfire with the police.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz and Remy Tumin

item.title: Officer Pleads Guilty to Manslaughter in George Floyd’s Death
item.description: J. Alexander Kueng was a rookie Minneapolis police officer when he held Mr. Floyd down while a fellow officer fatally knelt on his neck.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: David Joles/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: J. Alexander Kueng, left, arriving at court in St. Paul, Minn., in July.

item.title: Brazil’s Polls Were Wrong. Now the Right Wants to Criminalize Them.
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro and conservative lawmakers in Brazil are trying to make it illegal to publish polls that later do not match the election results.
item.dc:creator: André Spigariol and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in the first round of elections in Sao Paulo earlier this month.

item.title: A Prosecutor’s Change of Heart in a Capital Case at the Supreme Court
item.description: A district attorney in Texas, convinced that the evidence that sent Areli Escobar to death row was flawed, is supporting his request for a new trial.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Spencer Selvidge for The Washington Post via Getty Images
item.media:description: José P. Garza, a district attorney, joined lawyers for Areli Escobar, who was convicted of murder in 2011, in pushing for a new trial.

item.title: Home Remedies for Cold and Flu Symptoms
item.description: Here’s what we know about some of the most popular remedies that show at least a little promise.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Molly Matalon for The New York Times

item.title: Why Does Alcohol Mess With My Sleep?
item.description: Tips for getting a better night’s rest when your evening plans include drinking.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What Your Dog’s Behavior Means
item.description: Dogs are “really good at reading our emotions,” says one expert. But we’re not so good at reading theirs.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Nicolas Ortega; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: What’s the Best Nondairy Milk Alternative?
item.description: Soy milk, nut milks and other products may offer unique benefits.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: What is Microdosing, and Does it Work?
item.description: Scientists are split over whether the benefits some microdosers experience are a placebo effect or something more.
item.dc:creator: Dana G Smith
item.media:credit: River Cousin

item.title: Zar Amir Ebrahimi, an Iranian Exile, Channels Trauma in ‘Holy Spider’
item.description: Zar Amir Ebrahimi, who had to flee Iran after an intimate tape was leaked, has been transfixed by the protests erupting there as her film “Holy Spider” is released in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Elliott Verdier for The New York Times

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
